Tucson transforms beside Vestige, and nodds in readiness to fend off the en=
emy insectoids. He draws up one of the missile barrels from his cab, and at=
tatches it to his left arm.  He saves the second for later, just in case it=
 was needed.

" Time for a little pest control, Prime style.  All right Ves=
tige, ready when you are, let's put these bugs in their place and get Rodim=
us back."

--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Preston Carroll <supercyclonus@..=
.> wrote:
>
> > =A0<OLD>
> >
> > Tucson knew deep down that Vestige was a p=
art of Rodimus and that by relighting his spark, would hopefully rekindle t=
he spark in Rodimus as well. The exchange of energy was mysteriously not ta=
xing on Tucson as it would have been if he had transfered his own spark ene=
rgy into his chest. This was a power that was saved for many years in the h=
opes that one day, it's energy would be needed for a greater purpose. This =
was that day. And as Vestige came alive, his heart felt all the more energi=
zed as it filled endlessly with the joy of hope he had for his new friend.
=
> >
> > " I hope never to lose you my friend, you've helped me in more ways=
 than I can describe. You've given me new found hope that adversity can be =
overcome, and now I pass on that power of hope to you. We can do this, we w=
ill awaken Rodimus and through our compassion for each other, we may just b=
e able to exterminate this enemy for good."
> 
> <NEW>
> 
> Vesitige nodded=
, for once his movements were not the movements of an
> old machine but one=
 that was new and vibrant, as if he stepped off the
> assembly line. Vestig=
e slid out of Tuscon's cab and stood beside him,
> his body seemingly large=
r and more imposing. He turned to look at
> Tuscon, a familiar rougish look=
 on his features, similar to one that
> Rodimus may have worn at different =
times. "Yes it is time." His voice
> grim and determined.
> 
> With a deft =
movement and while being careful to keep his attacks away
> from the figure=
 on the table, he laid down some cover fire between he
> and the approachin=
g insectoid alien creatures to give Tuscon time to
> transform or to do wha=
tever thought he had in mind.
> 
> Meanwhile the figure on the table contin=
ued to stir, it was as if it
> was fighting something. It was only then tha=
t it became obvious that
> it was being held down by straps or tendrils. Th=
e figure's movements
> were steadily getting weaker as it attempted to figh=
t its way out.
> 
> As all this was happening a persistant buzzing and even=
 a rumbling
> could be heard in the background. It would seem that the atta=
cks had
> been noticed and something was comming!
